body: My Frenchie Gaston loves this food! His health has been improving too! I adore the quality of this product, after trying this, royal canin, and Merrick, I can say that at this price point you can't go wrong with Taste of the wild. If you're worried about switching from a grain based food like royal canin or science diet, or god forbid you've been using anything lower quality than purina pro plan, which I still find qualms with in the ing panel, taste of the wild offers a recipe with ancient grains too, so it won't upset your dogs digestive system if they're used to grains. My puppy is loving this and his stool quality is great. Though his farts are smellier than when on royal canin. I'd like to see less plant protein and a bigger animal protein content in the future from these guys. I've decided to rotate taste of the wild with essence dog food(very high quality, but pricey kibble loaded with animal protein to supliment the lack of animal protein in these slightly more budget friendly brands that still provide quality ingredients overall. There's room for improvement, but if you can afford this tier of kibble I highly recommend this brand over competitors. If you decide to incorporate something higher protein Essence and Carna4 are great to supplement a portion or all of their diet depending on your needs.

body: Dog loved this food that was slowly killing her I wish I had been better informed about the danger of grain-free dog food. We fed our golden retriever Taste of the Wild High Prairie grain free food for about 3 years. She ate well and was seemingly OK other than weight gain. She began to have an almost choking cough and we took her to the vet where she was diagnosed with an enlarged heart that was pressing on her trachea - making her cough. Now her heart is weaker and it is due to feeding her a grain free food because these foods lack Taurine which is important for their heart health. We were inadvertently slowly killing our otherwise healthy girl. Anyway, lesson learned - she is doing somewhat better on a grain inclusive diet now but the heart damage is not going to repair itself. Please pay attention to the "premium" or "boutique" labels, especially if they tout "grain free" as though it's good for your dog - it's not. We'll keep on loving our girl for the time she has left but we are pretty heartbroken that we, through our ignorance, have shortened her life.

body: Don't believe the negative reviews Got our pup in Nov. of 2018.  Did a lot of research, before deciding on TOTW brand.  A lot of people like to quote the FDA report (which I read, thoroughly), that listed this brand in their warnings of which ones to avoid.  Odd, that they would point out a top seller and favorite among owners and vet recommendations. Starting digging more into other sources of reviews and findings.  I believe it was a scare tactic, to force a company to go under.  Why?  Do your own research.  I've seen three different vets over these last three years, for various concerns (injuries not related to diet) and all were in agreement with TOTW as being a top 3 pick.  Here's what you need to do: 1.) Go to your LOCAL pet supplies store and buy from them.  Check the manufacture date and you'll find it's a fresher product.  2.) All dogs are different.  Experiment.  Buy the smallest bag possible and see how it goes. It does take a week or so, to adjust to a new food.  3.)  Tried all three flavors of TOTW and found out she has two favorites (less gas and firmer stools).  So, instead of changing back and forth, I spend the extra time, pre-mixing her two favorites, 1/1.  Guess what?  She's happy and never leaves any in her bowl and she's as healthy, strong and active as can be.  Buy local.

body: FDA HEART DISEASE WARNIG!!!! DON'T BUY IT The FDA released an extensive report on 27 June 2019 specifically naming Taste of the Wild as being suspect of causing chronic heart disease in dogs. The disease, canine dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), is life threatening and specifically linked to the heavy use of peas and other legumes as main ingredients, with Taste of the Wild being in the group of dog foods most frequently cited by veterinarians and pet owners as causing DCM.This was a 5-year clinical study with data from more than 500 veterinarians across the country--the largest ever scientific study of its kind.The full study is easy to read and gives a clear conclusion: Taste of the Wild and any food with a similar formula is a danger to dogs.The full study can be found on the FDA site, and Amazon should link to the study in the product description and issue a warning about this product (if they choose to continue selling it at all).

body: I regret buying this SO much! I recently adopted a dog who had been put on this food by their foster family, so I decided to keep her on it. Towards the end of her time with them (1 week), she started having accidents inside. After I brought her home her potty training regressed to the point she was having 3-5 accidents inside a day and peeing 30+ times a day outside. She was also drinking 10-15 cups of water a day. By week two she was practically incontinent - unable to hold it for 30 minutes and soiling her crate.After 3x trips to the vet, two rounds of antibiotics, complete bloodwork, urine tests, hundreds of dollars had been spent and nothing came back with any clues as to what was wrong. We were considering an ultrasound and urine culture.Then I decided to taper her off this food and onto something else. There was IMMEDIATE improvement, even just by swapping out 25% of this for something else. The vet thinks it was causing Fanconi Syndrome. Now she is totally off it, there are more accidents inside, no more accidents at night, and she is like a whole different dog!She is still drinking a lot but hopefully there won’t be lasting damage. I feel so bad I was feeding this to her and causing her so much discomfort.

body: Used Taste of the wild since it came out. Disclaimer!! I do not work for Taste of the Wild or any dog related industry.First my faithful Lab passed away last may 15th, she ate Taste of the Wild exclusively from the time I rescued her. The average age of a Lab is 10 to 12 years.  My lab was 16 years going nearly 17.  I had noticed her beginning to fail for about 6 months.  Spoke with vet and every thing checked fine.  We discussed her "end of life" plan.  She was just getting old.  One morning she didn't wake up, went in her sleep.She was checked by my vet once a year and sooner if something came up.  I was well aware of the lawsuit, but remember, this was a class action suit.  Could Taste of the Wild be a cause in younger dogs?  Three vets I used over the years told me it's unknown with any dog food regarding all the ingredients. A fact is dogs are living longer than ever, cancer is something that many pet owners will face according to the AKC. It is estimated that 1 - 4 dogs may get cancer.I just got a resuce dog last Saturday another Lab.  I will feed him Taste of the Wild.  Virtually every "kibble" pet food maker has had an issue, out there at one time or the other.  Some folks say people food, chicken, rice, grass fed beef, etc and what happens to people who eat these things some get cancer also, heart disease etc.OK know that was long, but I'm staying with something my dogs like and seem to be just fine with.

body: This is good dog food I feel the need to rebut the reckless comments made by some reviewers. The FDA has NOT issued any kind of warning concerning DCM and any connection to diet. They are simply gathering statistics. They have drawn NO conclusions nor found ANY evidence of a relationship. The FDA is drawing its information from approximately 500 cases reported in a 2 year period. Which when you consider how many dogs there are in the US makes DCM a VERY RARE condition which some breeds a genetically predisposed to. The most concerning statistic is that 90% of the cases were eating grain free food. As a result my Vet does not recommend any grain free food and states that certain grains have significant benefits in a dogs diet. They do highly recommend the taste of the wild brands that contain grain though. It is reckless and irresponsible to to toss around statistics and draw conclusions from them not supported by the facts or science of any sort and misstate facts simply to sow a little fear. If you have concerns about your dogs diet consult your vet and the AAFCO.

body: this brand is perfectly safe the fda fearmongering is nonsense. i've been feeding my german shepherd this brand for his entire life since he was 8 weeks old, and now he's 4 years old. he's extremely healthy, his coat is smooth, he has plenty of energy, and he loves this food. i switch between ancient grains and grain free periodically, because there's been a lot of discourse about whether grain-free is actually good for dogs or not, so at this point i have no idea about that but i figure switching between the two regularly is safe enough.people really need to stop putting so much faith in the fda. they're incredibly shady and can and have been bought to sell a narrative SO many times because capitalism. but if you're really that scared, take your dog for a checkup and ask a trusted vet their opinion. try out the food for a couple months and take the dog back for bloodwork, etc. if your dog is doing fine, the food is fine. but even if your dog isn't doing fine on this food, keep in mind that some dogs just individually have specific needs and may just need foods with certain ingredients. if your dog is getting sick off of a brand, it's usually not the brand's fault, it's just that your dog specifically needs to be on another food.anyway, i love this brand, and it's kept my dog very healthy and happy. i will continue to buy for as long as it exists.

body: Probable quality issues My dog dropped dead unexpected at just 10 years old. No health issues diagnosed prior to this. All tests were negative. One day it walked wobbly and looked like it got poisoning.  The next day we fed with home made food and everything returned to normal.  Bloodwork showed some results consistent with poisoning or cancer, we did a number of  other tests, but we didn't have enough time to investigate with ultrasounds or xrays. Other than that event and blood results my dog seemed fine. The same thing happened a few weeks later. However, this time my dog never got better. Husband gave this kibble in the morning, dog went outside, barely returned home, couldn't walk up stairs, and dog was dead within 5 minutes of eating this kibble.  Now, I think there might have been subtle signs that not everything was normal. Dog vomitted a few times in the prior month, it started to have problems holding urine, got more goo in her eyes, brown saliva stains from chin and paws completely disappeared (low RBC). The signs were so subtle and dog was so energetic that we, including our vet, didn't suspect a thing. The bloodwork, other tests, symptoms, suggest this food could have been slowly poisoning my dog and my dog might have had cancer that was consisistent with heavy metal contamination.  I feel this was my fault. When my dog was younger, I would buy kibble from various brands. Always buying quality or more expensive kibble.  However, in the last 7 years, I bought kibble only from this company, thinking it's high quality.  I didn't know about contamination with heavy metals at some manufacturing facilities, and I didn't know that grain free kibble may cause heart issues.  I dont know what happened or why my dog died exactly. But I now know that sticking with one brand may harm our dogs.  These companies don't truely know what is beneficial for all dogs in terms of food.  And now I know this brand's food might have had higher quantities of heavy metals (class action suit pending). If you must feed kibble, switch between brands, manufacturing facilities, and type of protein and grain used frequently.  That's all. I wish this company didn't advertise its kibble as high quality, because it really isn't.

body: BEWARE OF BAD BATCHES I have been buying Taste Of The Wild brand for my dogs for over 7 years now, tried all flavors and settled on the venison as my Pit's favorite. On my last order, as soon as I opened the bag the food smelled wrong, but i've smelled that kind of smell in their bags before so I dismissed it. I was also rushing out the door so I fed my dog and filled my sealed container. 24 hours later, my Pit, Layla had a skin rash with bumps all over her coat. I thought she brushed against something in the yard, gave her a wash with anti-fungal medicated shampoo and moved on with my day. The next day she was covered with rash again... At this point I decided to smell the dog food and realized it smells off... The best description to the foul smell would be that of a trash dump, or a fresh landfill mixed with rotten meat.I keep an emergency batch of food exactly for this purpose, so I gave Layle a fresh food the next morning. Immediately, the same day, the rash and the bumps were gone and her coat is shiny and back to normal.Amazon refunded my purchase no questions asked. Nevertheless, when I called the manufacturer to ensure they test the batch so other dogs would not suffer the same issues, they were very dismissive. Told me that I should contact Amazon for a refund and that they don't deal with customers directly. I tried to explain that I'm trying to be a responsible human and make sure this doesn't happen to others, but the lady on the line did not seem to care much.Thanks you Taste of The Wild for making my decision to move to a different brand easy. After 7 years and thousands of dollars spend, you lost a loyal customer.

body: Helped my doggie overcome an allergic reaction he had with other dog foods I purchased these because my old rescue dog was having problems with allergies when he ate the big box dry dog foods. The vet didn't have any ideas beyond a prescription (which helped short term, I admit) so I had to figure it out for myself.My first try was grain free dry dog food. Nope, that didn't work.Then I found these by accident, and I tried them. My dog is an indiscriminate eater, so the fact that he liked it didn't factor into the answer.It's now two months later, and he gets a can of this dog food with fresh brown rice from my rice cooker. The allergy is almost gone, and I have hope we're near the end. I'll also add that his coat is softer and smoother than it used to be, and he seems happy.Does that mean this is the solution for your dog? I can't answer that. All I can say is that it worked for my doggo.5/5*

body: Great Protein exactly what our dogs need I have two Siberian huskies both are 14 -15 we always look for high protein food and where so happy to find this one! body: I think this food made our previous dog sick, for years This review is so hard to write because I feel so guilty that I fed my dog this food for so long. Our corgi of 12 years was always a shedder for as long as I can remember. Everyone told me corgi's shed like crazy so we just thought that was his quirk. He passed away from liver failure Sept 2019. He ate Taste of the Wild dog food for as long as I can remember.  Forward to March 2020, we adopted a mutt and he came home with a different dog food - he was shiny and did not shed. We bought him Taste of the Wild dog food out of habit (new bag) and within 3 days he started shedding like crazy and his coat became dull. Could it be the dog food? No. I couldn't have done that for so long to our beloved corgi. We finished the bag of dog food, but when we were running low I decided to purchase the dog food that the shelter had sent him home with. Within 3 days he stopped shedding and within a week his glossy coat was back. Please, do not be like me. Please do not have to wonder if the dog food you chose may have poisoned your dog over the years. I will NEVER forgive myself for feeding our last dog this food.

body: Mixed Results Loyal user of Taste of The Wild High Prairie formula. It’s been the chosen diet My 4.5 year old German Shepherd since he was a puppy (one year on the puppy formula). No problems for him on the grain free Diet. He is a low keyed dog, but has high energy levels, up here in the Northwoods of Minnesota. He thrived on TOTW grain free.As with all dog owners, I have some concern with the DCM that may have a connection with grain free diets, so I figured, let’s give TOTW Ancient Grains High Prairie and see what happens.  I slowly rationed it into his diet over two weeks.  For a 75-80 pound German Shepherd, he receives the prescribed amount, soaked, divided into Morning and evening feedings.  My pup eats it with relish. He’s still an energetic dog. But, and this is a big but, his stools are now very loose, and rather inconsistent in when he voids. On the grain free, he was like clockwork (2, sometimes 3 per day)  with firm, dark stool. At first, all seems well. Dogs get into things in the woods, and sometimes they get sick from what they ingest.  Cause/correlation with Ancient Grains formula. Since then, his stool has been much looser, lighter color, and enormous volume, once perhaps twice per day.Verdict? I’m not sure. I find myself second guessing the rule-of-thumb, if it ain’t broke, don’t try to fix it. Reading other reviews, I’m now feel a bit more informed in regard to the loose stool (Other dogs have experienced the same problem), yet, that in itself can lead to anal gland problems.  Conclusion: finish the bag, and if stool doesn’t not improve towards end of bag, probably transition back to grain free formula.

body: Great Taste of the Ancient Wild Prairie Update★★★: He seemed better initially, but his symptoms came back and I’m now feeding another brand, whitefish and sweet potato grain free, and the results are much better and quicker to see. I only transitioned him with one day of a 50/50 mixture of the new stuff and the reviewed TOTW. No noticeable gastrointestinal upset or negative effects from such a quick switch and he’s doing great going on three weeks now. Paw licking is almost nonexistent and no gas, better breath and less ear scratching. He’s always a happy and upbeat dog, but he just acts like he feels better.Original review ★★★★★So far, so good! After years of being a happy customer of a different brand (NB) of grain-free venison & sweet potato (mixed occasionally with smaller amounts of their other grain-free formulas), my dog started licking his feet, began to have awful gas, and developed bad breath. When he wasn’t licking his feet, he was scratching his ears. These things came on gradually, not just as a result of a bad batch or an environmental change. The bad breath was the first thing I noticed, but chalked it up to aging. He’s a German Shorthaired Pointer that just turned 9 years old and has never suffered from allergies or digestive issues. (He goes where I go, so he occasionally snacks on different treats, snacks, or dog food at a friend’s place, always without issues.) When the other symptoms became apparent, I browsed reviews and noticed a growing number of unhappy customers using his current food. There was also a significant price drop on that food over the previous six months, though it has since gone back up.Since he primarily ate a venison recipe, I thought a switch to another brand’s venison formula would be easier on his digestive system. I’ve been increasing the amount of TOTW Ancient Prairie with his normal food over the past couple weeks and have already seen some improvement. He is still licking his feet and scratching his ears, but less frequently and with less vigor and decreasing with each passing day. His breath is better. He doesn’t clear the room due to his noxious rear end every night.He isn’t picky (and never has been) about food and is kind of a “grazing” eater. He didn’t get as excited for a new food as I’d expected, but he ate at a pace typical for him (which I think is better) and I started with a very low ratio. His eating habits haven’t changed and he eats about the same amount of food. He doesn’t have any noticeable digestive issues, such as vomiting or diarrhea, but he drops more poop per dump but dumps are less frequent.I’ll update my review and change the five star rating I gave Taste if the Wild Ancient Prairie if my dog’s situation changes, but I’m pleased with the food, with the reviews of others, the brand’s lack of recalls, and my dog’s response to it.To “those people” (you know who you are): Yes, I called his vet and discussed his symptoms. They had no serious concerns about his symptoms since he has no signs of dehydration, no rash, no behavioral changes, no incontinence, no diarrhea or vomiting, and is eating and drinking as per usual. They said I could bring him in, but a dietary change would likely be their first course of treatment. The vet office approved of this food and a gradual introduction of this food to his diet. As he is scheduled for his annual exam and vaccines in eight weeks, they’ll assess his issues and do any relevant testing if needed at that time. They advised me on other symptoms to watch for and invited us to come in if changing his food caused other symptoms,  made him worse, for peace of mind, or any other reason. If he worsens before his scheduled appointment or displays new symptoms, I will take him to his veterinarian. I’m communicating with his veterinarian, I’m not ignoring his symptoms, I’m not avoiding treatment because I don’t want to spend money, and I’m vigilant and keep record of things pertinent to his wellbeing. It frustrates me that responsible pet owners have to add information like this on a review of dog food to avoid fierce criticism from strangers who deem themselves experts on whether a person is worthy of having a canine companion. But I hope that this might help anyone (dog or person) having similar issues, is looking for information like this, or might find it useful in some way. This is meant to be a review of my experience with this product, not as criticism of the food that I’m removing from my dog’s diet.

body: Notice to consumers: PLEASE don't stop supporting this brand! I bought a bag of this for my dog and it seems like it's off because she hasn't been interested in it. I thought maybe it was sitting on a shelf somewhere for too long, so I started to research which flavors move the fastest with the intention to order that flavor as it would likely be fresher (I used to manage a large foodservice operation so this is familiar to me). What I found is a lot of people were having similar issues to me. Then I found that the FDA has issued a warning saying this brand (along with other grain-free/natural/holistic brands) are harmful to dogs. So it seems like many people believed this and stopped buying it, and now the bags are going bad since they'e not selling. What you need to know is that the FDA is very much in business with the GMO corn and GMO industry. They have a tight relationship (reference the documentary Food Inc and others). The pet food industry is a huge market. It is so easy to issue a "research paper" that says how "harmful" this healthy food is, which will then cause consumers to stop buying it and go to the brands they want us to buy, which are NOT pasture-raised and are loaded with GMO ingredients. This is how to effectively drive this company out of business. I have to say I have been feeding my dog ONLY this brand for her whole life, 5 years, and she is SO healthy, shiny smooth coat, no medical issues, very happy. I have had NO problems with this food, all different flavors. We need to help this company stay in business guys! If everyone can get over the initial issues with the recent bad bags and put your faith back into the brand, they can ride this out. It is called BLACK PROPAGANDA, a public relations tool used to drive a company out of business. I am not in any way affiliated with this company, but I have worked in the food business for a long time and I have seen this happen many times with the organic market vs the conventional market. I really hope you can think about this and continue to support this company. TOTW: you have my permission to repost this on Amazon on every flavor you sell.

body: Decent food, but gave our dog gas! We've been feeding our 6 year old German wire-haired pointer grain free dog foods for most of her life.  We've selected high quality foods and she's done well (e.g. high energy, attentive, etc.) with the various brands used.  Given the concerns over canine dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) and the possible association with grain free diets, we decided to try this dog food.  We gradually shifted her from Taste of the Wild (grain free) to Taste of the Wild (with ancient grains).  She seemed to like the "Ancient Grains" mix well and readily consumed it.  She also seemed to perform well while eating the food.  The main problem is that she seemed to have constant gas, which we never noticed with other dog foods.  Since then, we've switched her to another grain free dog food, and she seems to be doing well, and the gas episodes are substantially fewer!  As CDM is currently poorly understood, and the number of dogs affected is a very small percentage,  one recommendation is to rotate dog foods.  The assumption is that dog foods use different formulations, and that by rotating the foods the likelihood of a deficiency of any particular nutrient is reduced.  Hopefully, this will offset the potential to develop this disease.

body: Our 3 German Shepherds with food allergies loved it We live on a horse ranch, I have 3 German Shepherd that pretty much have free roam of the ranch all day long and trust me they play hard. So as you can imagine they get hungry. Also as you can imagine trying to find food that's reasonably priced that all 3 dogs like is somewhat difficult.Over the years we've tried more brands of dog food than you can imagine. Unfortunately German shepherds have a sensitive digestive system and can suffer from food allergies that manifest themselves as simple skin discoloration and itching to diarrhea. Trying new foods takes a bit of time because we need to slowly transition from one food to the next by slowly mixing the foods together and once fully transitioned  you need to keep them on that food for about a month or so before you know how well it's working. Unfortunately we only received 10 pounds of this food in two different flavors which isn't really enough to do a full review so I did something I hate to do, instead of  doing my normal slow transition I immediately switch them to the new food.. I will say that all 3 dogs really liked both flavors that we received and even though we didn't do a slow transition but rather immediately switched to the new food none of the dogs developed any rashes or apparent food allergies to the food which is a good sign, in fact  their bowel movements were perfectly normal which is saying something because once again we immediately switched them to the new food without doing the normal slow transition.I will add that I think the dogs like the salmon formula better than this roasted bison and venison The bottom lin,  if you have dogs with sensitive stomachs or food allergies I would definitely give this a try.
